keyTakeAways: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, signaling a major diplomatic rupture over drug trafficking and U.S. military actions.
This is the second such recall in 2025, following a prior diplomatic exchange in July when the U.S. summoned Colombia’s ambassador in Bogotá.
The U.S. accused President Gustavo Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods, escalating tensions.
The U.S. launched missile attacks on seven vessels suspected of drug trafficking, resulting in at least 30 deaths, with Petro claiming some of the victims were Colombian citizens.
Petro accused the U.S. of 'murder' and alleged U.S. support for a plot to remove him from power, a claim the White House dismissed as baseless.
A Colombian citizen aboard the most recent vessel attacked was returned safely to Colombia, underscoring the human cost of the conflict.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombia has recalled its ambassador to the United States, Daniel García-Peña, for consultations, amid escalating diplomatic tensions over U.S. military actions targeting alleged drug-smuggling vessels in the Caribbean. The move follows a previous diplomatic exchange in July and comes after President Donald Trump accused Colombian President Gustavo Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and threatened to cut subsidies and raise tariffs on Colombian goods. The U.S. has launched missile attacks on seven vessels, killing at least 30 people, including some alleged to be Colombians, prompting Petro to accuse the U.S. of 'murder' and supporting a plot to remove him from power. The conflict reflects broader issues of drug trafficking, national sovereignty, and economic retaliation between the two nations.
title: Colombian ambassador to US recalled to Bogotá for consultations, embassy says
